                        IntroductionAmong the numerous challenges confronting the 21st century, climate change stands as one of the most pressing issues, primarily driven by anthropogenic activities1. Our globe has witnessed enormous changes over the past few decades through evidence such as rising global temperatures, extreme rainfall patterns, extreme weather events, and numerous impacts on the life that resides on this planet including humans2. Beyond climate variability that occurs naturally, human-induced climate variation has had extensive negative effects on nature and people, including more frequent and powerful extreme events3. The possible consequences of climate change will be more visible in the Himalayan region, where glacier melt and snowmelt dominate flow4. Snowmelt contributes about 20% of annual stream flow in the Hindu Kush-Himalayan area, with a maximum contribution of \(\:>\)65% in the Indus watershed5. In the Sunkoshi basin, snowmelt contributes 6.1% and glacier runoff 10.5% of the total runoff, with snowmelt and baseflow together providing over 81.6% during the high crop water demand pre-monsoon period, while glacier runoff peaks at 11.5% from July to September6. Global warming intensifies the hydrological cycle, resulting in an accelerated rate of glacier and snowmelt in cryospheric-dominated basins. This process subsequently enhances downstream runoff, influencing water availability and hydrological regimes. This variability has consequences for both reservoir and Run off River (RoR) hydropower plants, the latter being more sensitive as the availability of flow varies with time as a result of climate change7.In 2022, global installed hydropower capacity increased by 26 GW to 1360 GW8. According to the International Energy Agency (IEA), hydropower will provide around 15% of global electricity generation in 2023–2030, with an average annual generation growth rate of close to 4%9. Also, Nepal’s hydroelectric generation increased significantly in FY2023, adding 500 MW for the second year in a row10. Nepal generated 1,050 MW of hydropower till 2012, and by 2023, this capacity had expanded to 2,800 MW, demonstrating remarkable development11. Developing a portion of Nepal’s hydropower potential has been shown to result in robust economic growth, significantly reducing poverty in the process12. Despite its potential benefits, Nepal’s hydroelectric growth is sensitive to climate change, which may have economic consequences13. The direct cost associated with the current climate variability and extreme events has been estimated to be equivalent to 1.5–2% of the current GDP/year and will be much higher in extreme years anticipated to rise by 5% or more which is higher as per the international levels14. So, the economic advancement and the overall prosperity of a nation directly or indirectly depend on how the natural resources, notably water, within the specific context of countries like Nepal are managed by their planners and policymakers through strategic decisions to ensure sustainable utilization of these crucial resources. Also, climate change may modify past hydrological patterns, leading to spatial and temporal variability in water flowing through rivers15. The predictability of water availability is hindered by this unpredictability, making it perplexing to optimize hydropower generation schedules. In the pursuit of optimizing energy generation, an assessment of the impacts due to climate variability and fluctuation in the river discharge becomes crucial.Nepal’s complex geology and varied topography render it highly vulnerable to climate change, particularly in terms of glacial dynamics and shifting precipitation patterns. These factors play a critical role in regulating river discharge, with profound implications for hydropower generation, agricultural productivity, and rural livelihoods16. Numerous researches have been conducted in several major river basins of Nepal by a number of researchers considering different General Circulation models (GCMs) developed by Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP) and considering various emission scenarios. By the end of the century, Nepal’s average surface temperature is projected to increase by approximately 5.8 °C17. In the mid-term, temperature rises are expected to range between 0.9 °C and 1.1 °C, while long-term projections indicate an increase of 1.3 °C to 1.8 °C18. As a result of the temperature rise, the snowcaps are likely to melt more quickly ultimately leading to extreme events such as pluvial floods and glacier lake outburst flooding, eventually causing damage to hydraulic structures that are intended to be constructed in the river. According to a study carried out for the West Seti River basin of Nepal, water yield was likely to escalate as a consequence of an upsurge in precipitation, with high flows anticipated to increase and conversely, low flows projected to decrease19. Similarly, fluctuations in the flow from a seasonal point of view are also vital. Despite the uncertainty and unpredictability associated with the assessment of climate variability, pre-monsoon and monsoon seasons are more likely to experience an upsurge, particularly during the monsoon season, which could cause widespread damage to infrastructure, livelihoods, and settlements in the future20. Also, future projections based on Regional Climate Models (RCMs) suggest a decrease of over 30% in monthly flow during drier months and an increase of more than 25% during high flow months compared to baseline values for the Koshi River Basin21. The synergistic effect of higher temperatures and increased precipitation leads to a 50% rise in discharge at the Kaligandaki River basin outlet, largely attributed to a projected 90% increase in snowmelt by the 2090s22. Climate-induced changes in temperature and precipitation in the Karnali River Basin are projected to increase future water availability, with annual discharge expected to rise by 6.4–8.4% under RCP 4.5 and by 5.1–10.9% under RCP 8.5 by 2040–2099, especially during pre-monsoon and monsoon seasons, likely intensifying later in the century23.Numerous studies that have been conducted for the comprehensive evaluation of climate change impact significantly in the context of river basins in Nepal were executed using the GCMs that were developed by CMIP5 and the Representative Concentration Pathways scenarios. Recently a new collection of scenarios has been created for ScenarioMIP, the section of the global CMIP6 of the World Climate Research Programme (WCRP) that includes scenario runs for the twenty-first century and these scenarios are known as Shared Socio-economic Pathways (SSP). This study attempts to consider the new SSP scenarios for the study, which will help visualize the climate change variations based on both socioeconomic as well as Greenhouse Gas (GHG) concentrations. High-resolution CMIP6 models provide improved simulations of precipitation patterns and temperature variability, capturing regional climate phenomena more accurately24. Additionally, updated parameterizations of physical processes, including cloud microphysics, aerosols, and land-surface interactions like vegetation dynamics and soil moisture, enhance the models’ ability to represent land-atmosphere interactions effectively25. While the models used in this study—GCMs, Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT), and Hydrologic Engineering Center’s Reservoir System Simulation (HEC-ResSim)—are widely applied in hydrological and climate change research, this study provides a unique contribution by integrating these tools in a novel way to address the challenges of climate change impacts on hydropower operations in Nepal. The SWAT model is widely used globally for hydrological studies due to its ability to simulate comprehensive processes and its user-friendly interface, making it ideal for diverse applications26. Additionally, the SWAT-CUP program’s semi-automated technique (SUFI-2) can assist users in performing more thorough sensitivity and uncertainty analysis27. HEC-ResSim is a software developed by the US Army Corps of Engineers, Hydrological Engineering Center (HEC) with US Federal Government resources28. HEC-ResSim is a multi-reservoir simulation model, effectively models water resource systems29. The SWAT-HEC-ResSim-GA framework underpins resilient reservoir management by enhancing understanding of complex systems and enabling uncertainty assessment from various sources across decision-making phases, fostering informed and adaptive water resource planning and operation30. Khatri et al. (2024)31 optimizes the reservoir operation in the Tamor basin storage project strategies using particle-swarm optimization, adapting to altered streamflow, mitigating pre-monsoon flow deficits, and enhancing annual energy generation and downstream dry-season flows. Previous studies have primarily focused on evaluating alterations in discharge and power generation within hydropower projects, neglecting to propose effective adaptation strategies in response to climate change. For instance, Pradhan et al. (2021)17 mainly focus on evaluation of CMIP5 GCMs for precipitation and temperature simulations in the Koshi River Basin. Budhathoki et al. (2021)19 assessed changes in water balance and hydrological extremes in the West Seti Basin but provided limited adaptation insights, and Dahal et al. (2020)23 modeled climate change impacts on water availability in the Karnali Basin. Operational strategies for hydropower adaptation are further needed. Consequently, it is imperative to develop an adaptation strategy, especially for complex projects like the Sunkoshi multipurpose project, which encompasses the construction of four distinct reservoir-type projects in series.This study aims to examine the alterations in the climate variables using seven GCMs developed by CMIP6 under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios. The impact of these alterations in the hydrological regime of the Sunkoshi River basin will be evaluated by examining the alterations in the flow and ultimately to the hydropower generations of four planned reservoir-type projects, namely Sunkoshi No.1, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.3 and Dudhkoshi. Furthermore, this study seeks to propose dynamic rule curves for cascading reservoirs in the Sunkoshi Basin to ensure sustainable and efficient hydropower generation. Unlike previous studies that primarily assessed the impacts of climate change on hydropower without proposing adaptive strategies, this study integrates dynamic rule curve modifications using climate projections and reservoir operation simulations. By iteratively adjusting reservoir levels based on projected flow changes, this study bridges the gap between hydrological modeling and real-time hydropower management, offering a novel operational framework for climate adaptation.Materials and methodsStudy areaThe Sunkoshi River Basin is a transboundary basin shared by Tibet (China) and Nepal, encompassing the catchment areas of key tributaries, including Bhote Koshi, Indravati, Tamakoshi, Likhu, and Dudhkoshi. Originating from the Zhangzangbo Glacier in Tibet32, the Sunkoshi River flows into Nepal, where the Indravati River joins it near Dolaghat. The river then meanders eastward through the valley formed by the Mahabharat Range and the Himalayas32. At Tribenighat, the Sunkoshi converges with the Tamur and Arun rivers to form the Saptakoshi. The basin extends from 85°23’13.2’’ E to 87°9’25.2’’ E longitude and 28°31’26.4’’ N to 26°34’58.8’’ N latitude, with elevation ranging from 111 to 8777 masl with catchment area of approximately 18,140 km2. This study deals with the four proposed Storage type projects: Sunkoshi No.3, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.1, and Dudhkoshi Hydropower projects. Figure 1 shows the study area map, highlighting the location of these four storage-type projects planned to be constructed in the Sunkoshi River basin. Table 1 provides a summary of the salient features of these four reservoir-type projects. Additionally, the basin includes two inter-basin transfer initiatives: the Sunkoshi Marin Diversion Multipurpose Project (SMDMP) and the Sunkoshi Kamala Diversion Multipurpose Project (SKDMP).Fig. 1Study Area Map showing Sunkoshi River Basin, Nepal.Full size imageTable 1 Salient features of storage type projects proposed by JICA33,34.Full size tableDataHydro-meteorological and temperature dataDaily hydrological data from 1990 to 2014 AD of stations located at Pachuwarghat, Rabuwa bazar, and Hampachuwar and meteorological data for the same period from 13 stations within the basin were collected from the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM), Nepal. However, most of these stations were located in lower-elevation regions, necessitating the integration of data from higher-altitude areas for a more comprehensive representation. To address this limitation, precipitation data from the Asian Precipitation–Highly-Resolved Observational Data Integration Towards Evaluation of Extreme Events (APHRODITE) database were incorporated. The reliability of APHRODITE’s daily precipitation estimates over Nepal was rigorously evaluated through comparative analysis with ground-based gauge observations35. Similarly, daily maximum and minimum temperature data of three stations: Dhulikhel, Jiri, and Okhaldhunga were collected and further used in the analysis.Digital Elevation Model (DEM), Land use and Land cover (LULC), and Soil data for hydrological modelingSWAT model requires DEM, LULC map, and Soil map for the preparation of a hydrological model7. NASA Digital Elevation Model (NASADEM) was downloaded from NASA’s official website and used for the watershed delineation. The LULC map for the Hindu Kush Himalayan (HKH) region as of 2010 AD was acquired from the International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD) website with an equivalent scale of 1:50,000. The soil Map for the basin was downloaded from the official website of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) for the United Nations. These maps were processed and clipped to the basin area using ArcGIS v.10.8.2 software. The resulting DEM, LULC, and soil maps are shown in Fig. 2.Fig. 2a DEM, b LULC, c Soil Map for the Sunkoshi River basin.Full size imageProjected climate dataIn this study, seven bias-corrected datasets from CMIP6-GCMs for the historic (1951–2014) and projected (2015–2100) climates for the two scenarios (SSP245, SSP585) were used. Mishra et al. (2020) have developed the daily bias-corrected data of precipitation, maximum and minimum temperature at 0.25° spatial resolution for South Asia and 18 river basins located in the Indian sub-continent36. SSP245 considers a middle of the road pathway which depicts an intermediate scenario with moderate challenges to mitigation and adaptation, population growth, substantial divergence in income trends among nations, and a level of cooperation between states, while SSP585 illustrates a high-emission, fossil-fuel-driven future with significant challenges. Together, these scenarios encompass a spectrum from low-mid to high emissions, allowing researchers to assess various climate impacts and uncertainties effectively37 and hence were selected for this study. The GCMs used in the research include ACCESS-CM2, BCC-CSM2-MR, CanESM5, EC-Earth3, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, MPI-ESM1-2-LR, and NorESM2-MM. The selection of GCMs for this study was based on multiple criteria to ensure robust climate projections over the Sunkoshi River basin. The chosen seven GCMs mentioned above were selected based on the following factors:
                
                  i)
                  
                    Performance in South Asia and the Himalayan Region: These models have been widely used in climate impact studies due to their ability to simulate monsoon variability and high-altitude climate processes, both of which are critical for hydropower assessment in Nepal.
                  
                
                
                  ii)
                  
                    Bias-Corrected Data Availability: The selected GCMs have high-resolution, bias-corrected datasets for South Asia36, which enhances their applicability for hydrological modeling.
                  
                
                
                  iii)
                  
                    Diversity in Model Structures and Origins: The selected models represent different modeling institutions and methodologies, reducing dependency on a single climate modeling framework and capturing a broader range of possible climate futures.
                  
                
                
                  iv)
                  
                    Use in Previous Studies: These GCMs have been utilized in prior hydrological and climate studies in Nepal and the South Asian region, ensuring their reliability in similar applications.
                  
                
                
                  v)
                  
                    Ensemble Approach for Uncertainty Reduction: Since individual GCMs may contain biases or uncertainties, using multiple models helps provide a more representative range of future climate conditions, minimizing the influence of outliers.
                  
                
              Reservoir system dataPhysical and operation data for the simulation of reservoir operation are required as an input in the HEC-ResSim38 that includes Elevation-Area-Volume (E-A-V) data, routing parameters, dam and spillway data, and information on evaporation and seepage losses. These datasets were acquired from reports prepared by the Nepal Electricity Authority (NEA) and prior studies carried out for these hydropower projects33,34.MethodologyThe prime focus of this study is to study the variations in precipitation, temperature, and discharge patterns across the past, present, and future time series and present a strategy for the operation of four substantial planned hydropower reservoirs in the Sunkoshi river basin that adapts to the varying climatic and flow patterns. To accomplish the objective of this study, the adopted methodology involved a series of stepwise sub procedures. These procedures incorporated the future climate projection employing a bias correction method, the development of a hydrological model in ArcSWAT 10.8, and finally the simulation of reservoir operation through HEC-ResSim 3.3 software. Figure 3 represents the adopted methodological framework.Projection of future climate scenariosThe future climate variables, specifically precipitation and temperature, were forecasted using downscaled GCMs developed by Mishra et al. (2020)36. The selected seven GCMs precipitation and temperature data underwent downscaling at local station levels, considering two distinct scenarios, SSP245 and SSP585. Since, the GCMs models possess higher resolutions, they tend to fail to imitate climate data at the basin scale due to biasness39. Therefore, bias correction is necessary to align the simulated data more closely with observed conditions before conducting impact assessments40.Temperature and precipitation simulations frequently exhibit significant biases due to systematic model errors or discretization and spatial averaging within grid cells, limiting the use of simulated climate data as direct input data for hydrological models40. To minimize the dissimilarity between observed and simulated quantities on a daily time step, bias correction processes were employed such that the model reflects the real-time phenomenon pretty well41. For this study, CMhyd software was employed for bias correction and downscaling the regional climate model to the local scale. CMhyd identifies biases between observed and simulated historical climate data and applies the same correction factors to future projections to ensure compatibility with hydrological models41. Among the various correction methods available for bias correction, Linear scaling (Multiplicative) and Linear scaling (Additive) were employed for precipitation and temperature variables respectively. The linear scaling method is comparatively simple for application and has almost similar accuracy as compared to the complex ones39. Furthermore, the effectiveness of the bias correction in these models was assessed by comparing the observed DHM data and the bias-corrected data through three statistical indices: Nash–Sutcliffe simulation efficiency (NSE), percentage bias (PBIAS), and coefficient of determination (R2) for three climate variables: Precipitation, Maximum temperature, and Minimum temperature, which are illustrated in Supplementary Table S.1- S.6 and Figure S.1-S.3.This study used the Multiple Model Ensemble approach for future climate projections. Preferably, utilizing the average of an ensemble of GCMs cancels out individual model errors and reduces ensemble uncertainty as more models are utilized42. The arithmetic ensemble mean is widely used in research, as it provides a better representation of observed data by reducing biases and errors present in any single model43. The ensemble approach reduces biases from individual models and provides a probabilistic range of future climate conditions.Fig. 3Methodological Flowchart.Full size imageHydrological modeling of watershed in SWATThe current study utilized the SWAT software as a foundational tool to simulate river discharge for historical and upcoming periods in the Sunkoshi River basin under various climate change scenarios. The model setup was conducted using ArcSWAT v.2018, which operates as a semi-distributed model. For setting up a watershed model, the first step involved dividing the watershed into sub-basins, which are delineated based on surface topography, ensuring that all regions within a sub-basin flow to its designated outflow44. After the sub-basin delineation, the Hydrological response unit (HRU) was defined. LULC, soil, and slope data were entered and reclassified for the development of HRUs. The completed model setup resulted in 46 sub-basins and 195 HRUs. The weather files were then loaded into the SWAT model after being updated in the SWAT database by creating a weather generator file. Climate data were also entered into the model, and the simulation was run on a daily time step for 25 years (1990–2014) with a 3-year warmup period (1990–1992). The simulation was followed by sensitivity analysis. Sensitivity analysis is a crucial aspect of developing hydrological models like the SWAT45. It involves assessing the influence of input parameters on model outputs. These analyses aid in understanding parameter behavior, optimizing model performance, and supporting robust decision-making in watershed management.Evaluation of hydrological modelThe model’s output precision is highly related to how effectively its parameters are calibrated, with a strong link to the observed data used during the calibration and validation stages. In this study, multi-station calibration and validation were employed at hydrological stations, namely Station 630, Station 670, and Station 681. The initial three years (1990–1992) were used for the warm-up period. Similarly, the model was calibrated between 1993 and 2002 whereas, the validation period was between 2003 and 2014. The performance of the model was evaluated based on three statistical parameters: R2, NSE, and PBIAS. Model simulation can be considered satisfactory if NSE > 0.50 and if PBIAS<\(\:\pm\:25\)\(\:\:\left[46\right]\). Also, if R2\(\:>\)0.5 model is considered acceptable47.After the calibration and validation processes, the calibrated parameters obtained were incorporated into the SWAT model for the development of a calibrated hydrological model. Subsequently, projected climate scenario data for the future were integrated into the model. The simulation was executed using a daily time step for a time period of 2018 to 2100. A preliminary warm-up phase spanning three years (2015 to 2017) was undertaken before the main simulation to ensure model stability. The principal aim of this simulation was to forecast the forthcoming discharge patterns.Simulation of reservoir operation in HEC-ResSimSimulation of reservoir operation under future climate scenarios was conducted using HEC-ResSim v. 3.3 software. The user interface of HEC-ResSim allows the development of a model in three stages, which include Watershed Setup, Reservoir Network, and Simulation. In the watershed setup module, the stream alignment of the Sunkoshi River basin was established by importing the shapefile of the river network. Computation points were then added to the alignment and the project elements which include the four reservoir projects and diversions. In the reservoir network module, the model schematic and its elements that include reservoirs, routing reaches, junction diversions, diverted outlets, and all their physical and operational data were defined. Operational data for the reservoirs were entered into the model, which incorporated four major operational zones: Flood Control, Conservation, Inactive, and Buffer zones. The rule curve that determines the reservoir pool elevation in different months of the year is defined as a buffer zone. Simulations were performed for a 22-year baseline period (1993–2014) using daily flow data and for two future climate scenarios—SSP245 and SSP585—over the period 2018–2100. Figure 4 represents the reservoir network model setup that was developed for the climate change impact analysis.Fig. 4Reservoir Model Setup developed in HEC-ResSim v. 3.3.Full size imageModification of reservoir rule curve in response to climate changeOptimal rule curves serve as essential guidelines in reservoir operations48. Given the projected change in future discharge, this study adopted a dynamic rule curve modification approach, which refers to the adaptive and time-sensitive updating of reservoir operation rules to align with evolving climate conditions. Unlike static rule curves that are fixed based on historical data, dynamic rule curves are re-optimized for each future period (2030s, 2060s, and 2080s) under different emission scenarios (SSP245 and SSP585). This allows for flexible and scenario-specific reservoir operations, enabling better energy generation outcomes and greater system resilience to climate change.Results and discussionAnalysis of future climate projectionsIn this study, an ensemble of seven GCM projections was utilized to project future climate variables for each station up to 2100 AD for two scenarios SSP245 and SSP585. Each projection was then looked out for three future timeframes: 2030s (2015–2039), 2060s (2040–2064) and 2080s (2065–2089). Climate analysis was done on a yearly and seasonal basis (Pre-monsoon, Monsoon, post-monsoon, and Winter) in all three futures for each station and all climate variables.Figure 5 illustrates the percentage rise in monthly precipitations across different time spans under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios. Notably, the projected changes exhibit irregular trends. In the 2030s, a substantial increase in precipitation is observed in September, reaching 33.81% under SSP245 and 36.51% under SSP585, while notable decreases occur in January, by 10.97% and 21.04%, respectively. Similarly, during 2060s large increase in precipitation can be seen in December by 37.01% and in May by 41.69% under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios respectively. In the 2080s, may shows the highest increase-34.79% under SSP245 and 50.40% under SSP585-whereas January records the most pronounced decrease, with 36.02% under SSP245 and 33.75% under SSP585. From a seasonal perspective, Precipitation increases during the pre-monsoon, monsoon, and post-monsoon seasons are projected under both scenarios, with larger changes under SSP585 in the 2080s. In contrast, winter precipitation is projected to decline consistently, particularly in January and February. SSP585 generally shows greater variability and extremes in precipitation compared to SSP245, reflecting its more severe emission scenario. These findings align with previous studies that report increasing pre-monsoon precipitation across the lowlands and high mountains of central Nepal, rising monsoonal precipitation in the middle mountains of the west and high hills of central Nepal, and a consistent decline in winter precipitation49.Fig. 5Change in monthly precipitation amount for the projected periods and scenarios (a) SSP245 and (b) SSP585.Full size imageThe percentage change in average monthly maximum temperature in different time periods under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios is depicted in Fig. 6. Under the SSP245 scenario, the maximum temperature is anticipated to rise by 1 –3 °C with a maximum upsurge observed for the 2080s. Similarly, under the SSP585 scenario the maximum temperature is projected to rise by 1 –10 °C with the highest rise occurred again for the 2080s. A seasonal analysis of the trends reveals that all seasons will experience a temperature rise, with winters showing the most significant spike in maximum temperatures. Figure 7 illustrates the percentage change in average monthly minimum temperature under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios. The minimum temperature is projected to increase consistently across all decades, ranging from 0.20 °C to 4.83 °C under SSP245 and 0.18 °C to 8.10 °C under SSP585. From a seasonal perspective, the analysis indicates that the monsoon season will witness a significant rise in minimum temperatures under both scenarios.Fig. 6Rise in monthly Maximum temperature for the projected periods and scenarios (a) SSP245 and (b) SSP585.Full size imageFig. 7Rise in monthly Minimum temperature for the projected periods and scenarios (a) SSP245 and (b) SSP585.Full size imageFigures 8, 9 and 10 represent a comprehensive climate change analysis conducted over a historical time span of 25 years (1990–2014 A.D) that compares the projections for three distinct future time periods: 2030s (2015–2039), 2060s (2040–2064) and 2080s (2065–2089). The three projected climate variables have been plotted for both scenarios SSP245 and SSP585. The shaded regions represent the ensemble width which quantifies the extent of variability within the outcomes derived from seven selected GCMs. The ensemble width was calculated by computing a \(\:\pm\:9\)5% confidence interval, offering a rigorous statistical characterization of the divergence between the predictions generated by seven GCMs and the central ensemble mean.Fig. 8Comparison of Historical and Future Precipitation Trends at Station Chaurikhark.Full size imageFig. 9Comparison of Historical and Future Temperature (Max) Trends at Station Jiri.Full size imageFig. 10Comparison of Historical and Future Temperature (Min) Trends at Station Jiri.Full size imageHydrological analysisEvaluation of the hydrological modelMulti-station model calibration and validation were carried out at Station 630 (Pachuwarghat), Station 670 (Rabuwa Bazar), and Station 681 (Hampachuwar) with a time span of 1993–2002 AD and 2003–2014 AD for calibration and validation respectively. A warmup period is deemed necessary to stabilize the model48 so, the initial three years (1990–1992) were allocated as the warmup period. Calibration was carried out using Sequential Uncertainty Fitting Ver-2 (SUFI-2) as an optimization algorithm which is made available by SWAT-CUP software. Initially, a range of minimum and maximum values was assigned to each parameter and after running the simulation, SWAT-CUP generated the values that fitted the best for the model which were later used for developing a calibrated model in ArcSWAT. The model was run on daily time steps for all three hydrological stations. Simulations were carried out for 500–1000 iterations, and once satisfactory statistical indices were achieved, the model underwent a final phase of refinement with 2000 iterations.Additionally, global sensitivity analysis was performed in SWAT-CUP. The most sensitive parameter is based on the values of the t-stat and p-value. t-stat and p-value are used to identify each parameter’s relative significance. The t-stat is the ratio of the parameter coefficient to its standard error. A higher absolute t-stat value indicates a greater influence of the parameter on the model output, while a lower p-value (p ≤ 0.05) suggests statistical significance27. The top 10 sensitive parameters are presented in Table 2.Table 2 Ranking of the top 10 sensitive parameters based on the t-stat and P-Value.Full size tableTo provide station-specific insights into model sensitivity, the four most influential parameters identified during the calibration process were extracted separately for each of the three hydrological stations used in the multi-station calibration. These parameters were selected based on their statistical significance, particularly their t-stat and p-value values derived from the SUFI-2 algorithm in SWAT-CUP. In addition, Fig. 11 represents the recorded and simulated daily flow during the calibration and validation period at Station 630, Station 670, and Station 680. The findings pertaining to the percentage alterations in flow within the framework of the SSP245 scenario underscore a noticeable variability in discharge across distinct months. The result of the calculations is demonstrated in Table 5; Fig. 14. For the baseline period, the energy generation ranges from 1648.88 GWh/yr for Sunkoshi No.3 to 2963.55 GWh/yr for Dudhkoshi. In the SSP245 scenario, energy generation is projected to increase for all plants over time. For the 2030s, Sunkoshi No.1, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.3, and Dudhkoshi are estimated to produce 2939.30 GWh/yr, 2870.09 GWh/yr, 1766.77 GWh/yr, and 3100.82 GWh/yr, respectively. The same trend goes on for the 2060s and 2080s, where the highest increase is for the 2080s: Sunkoshi No.1, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.3, and Dudhkoshi have estimated energy generations of 3258.38 GWh/yr, 3082.27 GWh/yr, 1838.91 GWh/yr, and 3186.79 GWh/yr, respectively.In the SSP585 scenario, the rise in energy generation is more prominent compared to the SSP245 scenario. Plants are estimated to generate 3057.51 GWh/yr, 2932.04 GWh/yr, 1784.71 GWh/yr, and 3133.18 GWh/yr by the 2030s, while Sunkoshi No.3 and Dudhkoshi will already have exhibited a considerable rise. During the 2060s, these increments become even greater, with Sunkoshi No.1, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.3, and Dudhkoshi expected to yield 3427.12 GWh/yr, 3207.23 GWh/yr, 1864.51 GWh/yr, and 3192.60 GWh/yr, respectively. It is expected that the 2080s would see the biggest increases in the largest generation, where Sunkoshi No.1 and Sunkoshi No.2 are estimated at about 4072.33 GWh/yr and 3852.88 GWh/yr, respectively. Others that have shown high growth include Sunkoshi No.3 and Dudhkoshi, estimated at about 2067.69 GWh/yr and 3273.94 GWh/yr, respectively. Notably, Sunkoshi No.1 is expected to witness a remarkable 70.15% increase in generation during the 2080s under the SSP585 scenario.Table 5 Summary of energy generation (GWh/yr) of four hydropower plants for baseline period and future periods.Full size tableFig. 14Percentage change in average yearly generation for the projected periods and scenarios (a) SSP245 and (b)SSP285.Full size imageModification of rule curve: a strategy for maximization of energy generation in response to climate change.Based on the analysis of variations in energy generation resulting from climate change impacts, it can be concluded that energy generation is likely to increase in the future. To optimize hydropower generation under future climate scenarios, six different rule curves were developed for each of the four reservoir projects: Sunkoshi No.1, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.3, and Dudhkoshi. These rule curves were iteratively refined in HEC-ResSim by adjusting reservoir levels in response to projected flow variations under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios. The six rule curves are designed to maximize energy generation while ensuring operational feasibility. Each rule curve incorporates different reservoir storage strategies based on expected seasonal inflows and hydropower demand. A summary of the key characteristics of each rule curve is presented in Table 6.Table 6 Summary of the six proposed rule curves and their Characteristics.Full size tableAmong the six rule curves, Rule Curve 01 and Rule Curve 05 serve as important benchmarks for comparison. Rule Curve 01 represents the baseline static operation strategy, helping assess the benefits of future modifications. Rule Curve 05 reflects a high-end adaptation scenario, incorporating assumptions of significant infrastructure changes required to capture increased high-flow volumes under the extreme SSP585 pathway. While these two curves may appear less promising in terms of immediate feasibility or performance, their inclusion provides boundary conditions to compare the performance and practicality of more operationally flexible curves (e.g., Rule Curve 04 and Rule Curve 06). This comparative evaluation forms the basis for recommending Rule Curve 06 as the most robust and dynamic strategy across future conditions. Each rule curve was evaluated for its effectiveness in maximizing hydropower generation while maintaining operational flexibility. Rule Curve 06 consistently achieved the highest energy gains across different future periods (2030s, 2060s, 2080s), making it the most suitable for future climate conditions.Figure 15 represents the modified rule curves for Sunkoshi No.3, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.1, and Dudhkoshi respectively under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios. The adjustments made to the rule curves for Sunkoshi No.3 were designed to optimize energy generation while maintaining operational feasibility under projected climate scenarios. Notably, in Rule Curve 06, the lowest reservoir level in June is 685 m, compared to 680 m in the baseline case. This adjustment was made based on anticipated increases in early runoff due to enhanced snowmelt and pre-monsoon precipitation under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios. The rationale for this modification includes:
                    
                      i)
                      
                        Enhancing hydropower generation by retaining more water before peak monsoon months, ensuring better energy production during dry seasons.
                      
                    
                    
                      ii)
                      
                        Aligning with projected inflow variations, where higher early-season inflows reduce the risk of storage depletion.
                      
                    
                    
                      iii)
                      
                        Maintaining reservoir operation efficiency, ensuring sustainable year-round power production.
                      
                    
                  While this adjustment results in slightly reduced flood absorption capacity during the June–August period, the rule curves were designed with flexible outflow strategies to manage inflows dynamically. The reservoir’s operational policies allow for controlled releases to mitigate flood risks while maximizing power generation efficiency.Fig. 15Modified Rule curves under SSP245 AND SSP585 scenarios for projected periods for (a) Sunkoshi No.3 (b) Sunkoshi No.2 (c) Sunkoshi No.1 (d) Dudhkoshi.Full size imageFig. 16Percentage increase in average yearly generation for six proposed rule curves across various periods under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios for (a) Sunkoshi No.3 (b) Sunkoshi No.2 (c) Sunkoshi No.1 (d) Dudhkoshi Hydropower Projects.Full size imageTable 7 represents a summary of the average yearly energy generation for projected periods under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios for the four reservoir-type projects. The outcome of the simulation represents that through the futuristic modification of the rule curve, the maximization of energy generation was made possible as energy increased from 7 to 26% across various periods for Sunkoshi No.1. A maximum increase in generation was observed for the 2080s when rule curve no: 06 was used. For Sunkoshi No.2 the maximum increase in generation was observed for the 2080s as presented in Table 7. The percentage increase in generation varied from 19 to 61% when compared with the baseline period with maximum escalation observed for the 2080s when using rule curve no: 05. The Sunkoshi No.1 project may experience a rise of 23–71% in the generation when the rule curve is modified for different periods. Notably, the implementation of Rule Curve 06 is expected to result in the most significant increase in power output, particularly during the 2080s. According to the findings of the comparative analysis, the Dudhkoshi power plant is expected to experience an upsurge in the generation varying from 4 to 10%. Notably, it is projected that the most significant rise in energy production will be visible during the 2080s, primarily if the reservoir is operated using the rule curve no: 06. The percentage increase in average yearly generation for six proposed rule curves across various periods when compared with that of the baseline period for Sunkoshi No.1, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.3 and Dudhkoshi hydropower projects is presented in Fig. 16.Table 7 Summary of average yearly energy generation for projected periods under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios.Full size tableThese results suggest that the adoption of this adaptation strategy would ultimately benefit the nation’s energy sector. By incorporating these optimized rule curves, a considerably greater amount of energy will be generated when compared with the energy output that would have been produced if the rule curve that was employed during the baseline period is implemented for future timelines. On the contrary to former research that accounted for the impact of climate change on hydrology, this study offers a new perspective on dam-operating conditions, suggesting a path of enhanced operational ability by continuously changing the rules of runoff. This proposes the path that bridges hydrological modeling with everyday dam operations, and thus presents a broader framework for addressing climate-induced challenges to hydropower. Uncertainty assessments of climate projections, reservoir storage dynamics, extreme weather events, human activity conditions, shifts in water demand and model structures are other factors that could impact the hydropower generation.Comparison of rule curve performance and practical implicationsThe six proposed rule curves were evaluated under both SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios, considering projected inflow variations and seasonal water availability. The comparative analysis revealed the following key findings:
                  
                    i)
                    
                      Rule Curve 01 (Baseline) showed minimal adaptation to future climate change, resulting in suboptimal energy generation in the later decades.
                    
                  
                  
                    ii)
                    
                      Rule Curves 02 and 03 improved dry-season and monsoon generation, respectively, but did not achieve year-round efficiency.
                    
                  
                  
                    iii)
                    
                      Rule Curve 04 provided a balanced operational strategy, ensuring steady energy output while minimizing extreme variations.
                    
                  
                  
                    iv)
                    
                      Rule Curve 05 demonstrated the highest increase in energy generation under SSP585, but required significant modifications to reservoir infrastructure.
                    
                  
                  
                    v)
                    
                      Rule Curve 06 emerged as the most effective strategy, adapting dynamically to seasonal variations, maximizing energy generation across all timeframes, and ensuring resilience under both emission scenarios.
                    
                  
                The study highlights the importance of flexible reservoir management strategies in adapting to climate-induced hydrological changes. While Rule Curve 06 is recommended for future implementation, additional assessments considering multi-objective optimization (e.g., flood control, irrigation, ecological flows) should be explored in future research to ensure broader applicability.Trade-offs in rule curve adjustments: energy optimization vs. flood absorption capacityOne of the key challenges in reservoir management is balancing energy generation optimization with flood absorption capacity. In the case of Sunkoshi No.3, the proposed Rule Curve 06 increases the minimum June reservoir level to 685 m, compared to 680 m in the baseline case, resulting in an estimated storage decrease of ~ 55 million m³. In this case, energy generation in 2080s (SSP245) and 2080s (SSP585) increases from baseline 1648.88 GWh/yr to 1852.94 GWh/yr and 2069.30 GWh/yr respectively. This adjustment is necessary to capture early runoff and improve dry-season power availability. However, a higher reservoir level during the pre-monsoon period could potentially reduce the available storage for absorbing peak monsoon inflows. To address this trade-off, the following considerations were made:
                  
                    i)
                    
                      The rule curves incorporate projected inflow variations, ensuring that the reservoir is operated within safe limits.
                    
                  
                  
                    ii)
                    
                      The dynamic and adaptive nature of reservoir operations allows for timely pre-monsoon releases if inflow projections indicate higher-than-average monsoonal inputs, thus preserving flood absorption volume without compromising energy output.
                    
                  
                  
                    iii)
                    
                      The reservoir management strategy remains flexible and responsive, enabling operators to adjust operations in real-time based on inflow conditions, thereby supporting both energy reliability and flood risk mitigation.
                    
                  
                  
                    iv)
                    
                      The cascading configuration of the Sunkoshi hydropower system allows for inter-reservoir coordination, whereby upstream and downstream reservoirs can be operated complementarily, thereby distributing both energy generation and flood buffering responsibilities across the system more efficiently.
                    
                  
                This study emphasizes that while rule curve modifications prioritize energy maximization, they are designed with sufficient operational flexibility to handle climate-induced hydrological variability. Future work should therefore incorporate multi-objective optimization frameworks that couple rule curve adaptation with real-time flood forecasting tools and downstream risk assessments to ensure comprehensive and climate-resilient reservoir performance.Model uncertainty and limitationsClimate projections inherently involve uncertainty due to variations in model structures, parameterization schemes, and emission scenarios. In this study, we adopted a multi-model ensemble approach using seven CMIP6 GCMs to minimize the impact of individual model biases and uncertainties. While this improves the robustness of projections, some limitations remain.
                    
                      i)
                      
                        Inter-Model Variability: Different GCMs exhibit variations in simulating precipitation and temperature patterns, particularly in complex mountainous terrains. The spread of projections across models highlights the inherent uncertainty in future climate conditions.
                      
                    
                    
                      ii)
                      
                        Bias Correction Assumptions: The bias correction technique assumes that past climate biases will remain consistent in future projections. However, climate feedback mechanisms may evolve differently, leading to residual errors.
                      
                    
                    
                      iii)
                      
                        Lack of Dynamical Downscaling: While the use of bias-corrected GCMs improves spatial accuracy, employing high-resolution RCMs through dynamical downscaling could further refine climate projections, particularly for localized hydrological responses.
                      
                    
                    
                      iv)
                      
                        Scenario Dependence: The study focuses on SSP245 and SSP585, which capture a broad range of climate futures, but additional scenarios such as SSP370 were not included. While SSP370 represents an alternative socio-economic pathway, its projected climate outcomes largely fall between SSP245 and SSP585, making it less critical for this hydropower-focused study.
                      
                    
                    
                      v)
                      
                        Hydrological Model Uncertainty: The SWAT and HEC-ResSim models, though widely used, introduce their own uncertainties related to input data quality, calibration parameters, and simplifications in representing real-world hydrological processes.
                      
                    
                  Future research could refine these projections by incorporating additional climate models, regional downscaling approaches, and uncertainty quantification techniques to improve hydropower resilience planning under climate change.ConclusionsThis study investigated the impacts of climate change on hydropower generation in the Sunkoshi River basin and proposed a dynamic rule curve adjustment method to enhance hydropower resilience by conducting a projection of climate variables by downscaling the regional-scale climate models that were downscaled from the global scale to the basin scale by utilizing seven CMIP6 GCM models under SSP245 and SSP585. The trend in precipitation, according to the analysis, shows a lot of variation in SSP245 and SSP585. The SSP245 projects an overall increase of 37.01% in precipitation during the pre-monsoon, monsoon, and post-monsoon seasons, peaking in May 2080s, with a minimum of 36.02% decrease projected over January 2080s. Similarly, SSP585 forecasts maximum precipitation increase in May 2080s and a dip in January. Temperature trends show consistent rises, with maximum increases in monthly maximum temperatures of up to 3.47 °C (SSP245) and 10.41 °C (SSP585), notably in winters, and monthly minimum temperatures rising by up to 4.83 °C (SSP245) and 8.10 °C (SSP585), especially in July 2080s. Discharge analysis under both scenarios reveals an ascending trend from March to June, followed by a positive but diminishing trend, turning negative from January onwards as winter approaches. The paper proposed a climate change impacts adaptation strategy; it pursues the modification of the rule curve for four storage projects, aiming at energy generation optimization, taking into consideration the downstream reservoir cascading effects. These approaches, after successive iteration, lead to six different rule curves for various timelines that result in increases of energy generations: ranging from 7 to 25.5% for Sunkoshi No.3, 19–61.07% for Sunkoshi No.2, 23–71.26% for Sunkoshi No.1, and 4–10.50% for Dudhkoshi power plants.This study demonstrates that dynamic, scenario-specific rule curves can serve as a proactive adaptation strategy, enhancing both energy security and operational resilience under uncertain climate futures. However, the study does not incorporate changes in LULC or sediment impacts. While these factors are crucial for sustainable reservoir management and to ensure robust predictions. This study serves as a preliminary investigation, suggesting future researchers consider integrating these aspects to enhance the study. The findings of this study provide insights for reservoir system operators and water resource managers in developing strategies for adapting to climate change hydropower reservoir management, emphasizing the necessity of proactive adaptation strategies to sustain hydropower generation under changing climatic conditions. By adopting dynamic rule curve adjustments, hydropower systems can achieve greater resilience, contributing to energy security and sustainable development in the Himalayan region and beyond.

items.title: Ponte di Messina, nuovo ricorso delle associazioni
items.description:
Greenpeace, Legambiente, Lipu e WWF chiedono al CIPESS il ritiro in autotutela della delibera che sbloccherebbe l’opera
The post Ponte di Messina, nuo
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il Giaguaro In evidenza Adotta una specie L’Italia vìola le norme europee sulla concorrenza Le Associazioni ambientaliste Greenpeace, Legambiente, Lipu e WWF hanno presentato un nuovo reclamo all’Unione Europea denunciando come si vorrebbe realizzare il Ponte sullo Stretto di Messina senza procedere all’affidamento lavori tramite gara pubblica internazionale. In particolare le Associazioni ritengono che ci sia una reiterata violazione da parte dell’Italia degli artt.101/109 del TFUE e dell’art.72 della Direttiva 2014/14/UE sulla concorrenza. Il nuovo reclamo è il quarto presentato dalle Associazioni e si aggiunge a quello per la mancata applicazione della Direttiva sulla Valutazione Ambientale Strategica (Direttiva 2001/42/CE recepita in Italia dal Testo Unico Ambientale, Decreto Legislativo n. 152/2006) ed a quelli presentati avverso i due pareri della Commissione VIA VAS per la non corretta applicazione della Direttiva 92/43/CEE detta “HABITAT” e della Direttiva 2009/147/CE per la “Conservazione degli uccelli selvatici”. Manca gara d’appalto internazionale Il nuovo reclamo ripropone il tema della mancata gara d’appalto internazionale per la realizzazione del Ponte contestando l’interpretazione normativa che è stata data per evitarla. Infatti nonostante l’avvenuta messa in liquidazione della SdM avvenuta nel 2013 e i conseguenti atti caducati che regolavano i rapporti di concessione, il Governo ha inteso ripristinare integralmente i rapporti preesistenti facendo scegliere al Parlamento la soluzione di attraversamento stabile dello Stretto di Messina attraverso la realizzazione del ponte a campata unica progettato dal SdM sulla base dell’aggiudicazione dell’opera avvenuta 24 novembre 2005 e, inoltre, e sulla base di un’offerta di 3,9 miliardi avanzata dal consorzio Eurolink. Al di là della condivisione o meno sulla scelta dell’opera (comunque contestata dalle Associazioni), ed al di là dell’interpretazione che si può dare sulla soluzione di continuità avvenuta nel 2013 nei confronti della SdM e dei rapporti di questa finalizzati alla realizzazione dell’opera, il reclamo afferma che il Governo Italiano avrebbe dovuto procedere, invece, ad una nuova gara internazionale. In particolare, si ritiene non corretto il riferimento su cui è stato calcolato l’incremento dei costi che la normativa vigente -per non procedere a nuova gara- ritiene ammissibile sino ad un massimo del 50%. L’appalto oggi stimato in oltre 13,5 miliardi (per altro ampiamente sottostimati) secondo le Associazioni non può essere realizzato dallo stesso soggetto che nel 2005 lo aveva vinto per 3,9 miliardi su un progetto che poi avrebbe subito progressive modifiche e un’importante estensione delle opere connesse e di quelle compensative. Il reclamo trasmette all’Unione Europea la posizione e i documenti dall’ANAC che, anche in sede di audizioni parlamentari, aveva sollevato dubbi sulla mancata applicazione della Direttiva concorrenza e quindi sulla mancata nuova gara internazionale. L’ANAC sul tema dal 2023 è rimasta inascoltata sebbene nell’ultima audizione svolta alla Camera il 9 giugno 2025 quindi ben prima della delibera CIPESS, tramite il suo Presidente Avv. Giuseppe Busia abbia esplicitamente affermato: “L’aver deciso di non svolgere una nuova gara in coincidenza della riattivazione del percorso per la costruzione del ponte sullo Stretto pone dei vincoli sui costi dell’opera: questi, infatti, non possono crescere oltre il 50% del valore originariamente messo a gara. Ciò, in base alla direttiva europea, che in certi casi consente di non attivare una nuova procedura concorrenziale, ma entro tali limiti”. Inviata anche una nota al CIPESS Le Associazioni ambientaliste Greenpeace, Legambiente, Lipu e WWF hanno poi inviato al CIPESS una nota con cui chiedono il ritiro in autotutela della delibera n. 41 del 6 agosto 2025 con cui il Governo ha chiuso l’iter di approvazione del Ponte, delibera ancora sospesa perché all’attenzione della Corte dei Conti che ha già avanzato puntuali rilievi. Al di là delle risposte che il Governo fornirà ai rilievi della Corte dei Conti, la richiesta delle Associazioni elenca i gravi elementi di criticità già esposti nei ricorsi presentati al TAR Lazio e nei reclami inoltrati all’Unione Europea. Le Associazioni sono consapevoli che già la Corte dei Conti in assenza di risposte ai rilievi avanzati ha invitato il CIPESS a ritirare in autotutela la delibera n. 41 del 6 agosto 2025, ma ritengono che qualunque siano le risposte che verranno fornite all’interno del controllo preventivo di legittimità queste non possano superare né tanto meno sanare le problematiche ed i vizi del procedimento deliberativo del CIPESS.

items.title: Atlante anfibi e rettili, il 25 ottobre la presentazione a Roma
items.description:
Un Atlante completo e aggiornato sulla distribuzione di tutte le specie di anfibi e i rettili presenti in Italia
The post Atlante anfibi e rettili, il
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il Giaguaro In evidenza Adotta una specie Appuntamento all’Università di Roma Sapienza L’Italia annovera 54 specie di rettili (di cui il 19% minacciate) e 43 di anfibi (36% minacciate). Una specie di anfibio su 3 (ben 14) sono endemiche, vivono cioè solo nel nostro Paese. Proprio gli anfibi, a causa della distruzione delle zone umide, dei cambiamenti climatici e della introduzione di specie aliene, risultano essere la classe maggiormente minacciata, non solo nella nostra penisola ma a livello globale secondo l’IUCN, l’Unione Internazionale per la Conservazione della Natura. Per far luce su questi animali assai poco conosciuti se non osteggiati, è in arrivo il nuovo Atlante degli Anfibi e Rettili d’Italia, che sarà presentato il 25 ottobre a Roma. Un volume completo e aggiornato sulla distribuzione di tutti gli anfibi e i rettili presenti in Italia. Per ogni specie vengono fornite informazioni approfondite sulla biologia, l’ecologia e sullo stato di conservazione. Presentazione Sabato 25 ottobre ore 10, 30 – Sapienza – Università di RomaDipartimento di Biologia e Biotecnologie Charles DarwinViale dell’Università, 32 – ROMA Locandina presentazione Atlante La redazione delle schede è stata affidata a oltre 100 esperti della Societas Herpetologica Italica, che hanno analizzato un imponente database composto da più di 265.000 segnalazioni, raccolte grazie al contributo di migliaia di osservatori. I testi sono arricchiti da splendide immagini di alta qualità, scattate in natura da fotografi-erpetologi. Il risultato è un’opera corale di grande valore scientifico, che costituisce un punto di riferimento fondamentale per studiosi, ricercatori e professionisti, ma anche una guida preziosa per gli appassionati e per chi vuole saperne di più su questi affascinanti animali. Wildlife Il valore della piccola fauna L'importanza di rettili e anfibi per un'agricoltura sostenibile Biodiversità fragile, maneggiare con cura Al recente Forum dei volontari WWF di Caserta il WWF ha presentato il nuovo report “Biodiversità Fragile, maneggiare con cura: Status, tendenze, minacce e soluzioni"

items.title: Reply to: Observed warming of cold extremes is not captured with a fixed threshold definition
items.body:
Download PDF

Matters Arising
    
        
            Open access

Published: 08 October 2025

Reply to: Observed warming of cold extremes is not captured with a fixed threshold definition
                    Judah Cohen 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-7762-44821,2, Laurie Agel3, Mathew Barlow3 & …Dara Entekhabi2 Show authors

Communications Earth & Environment

volume 6, Article number: 796 (2025)
            Cite this article
                    
                    
        
        
            
                
                    
                        257 Accesses
                    
                
                
                
                    
                        
                            5 Altmetric
                        
                    
                
                
                    
                        Metrics details

Subjects
        
            Atmospheric dynamicsClimate change

The Original Article  was published on 08 October 2025

replying to R. Blackport & M. Sigmond Communications Earth & Environment https://doi.org/10.1038/s43247-025-02629-y (2025)Blackport and Sigmond1 argue that in Cohen et al.2 our method of computing trends on cold extremes (that is, keeping the definition of a cold extreme fixed over the entire period (coldest 5% of days 1960–2023)) artificially masked any warming trends in cold extremes. We chose this method to avoid the case where no trend appears in a limited period, for example, since 2000, but clearly, the cold extremes are warmer than in the previous period 1960–2000 due to the warming being more of a step function than a gradual trend. By keeping the definition of a cold extreme fixed across the entire period of analysis, we believed that would make it harder to identify a cold extreme in the latter milder winters. Alternatively, with a moving or non-fixed definition of a cold extreme in effect, we would be comparing cold extremes that were defined differently across periods, and not a consistently defined cold extreme.Blackport and Sigmond1 use synthetic data to demonstrate that, even with warming temperatures including cold extremes, by using a fixed threshold no statistically significant trends can be detected in cold extremes. If, instead, cold extremes are defined only within the period of analysis, then the warming trend in cold extremes can be correctly detected. We did consider computing the trend in cold extremes using a moving threshold as suggested by Blackport and Sigmond1 where cold extremes are computed only in the period for which the trend is being considered. We also acknowledge that no metric of measuring a trend in cold extremes is perfect, and multiple methods and metrics are likely needed for a comprehensive understanding of changes in cold extremes.We show box and whisker plots of Arctic and CEUS temperature, where cold extremes are computed for each decade separately in keeping with the guidance of Blackport and Sigmond1. In the Arctic (Fig. 1), both cold extremes and mean temperatures have steadily warmed, and post-2010, none of the observed cold extremes reach the extremity of the warmest cold extremes observed before 1980. In the CEUS (Fig. 2), the box and whisker plot does not resemble so much a linear warming trend across the decades but more like a step function with cold extremes and mean temperatures steady from 1960 through 1990 and again steady from 1990 through the present at a warmer temperature. Visually there is no trend in cold extremes during the period of AA (post-1990) in the CEUS, even though a moving threshold is applied. And in stark contrast to Arctic temperatures, cold extremes in the CEUS in the most recent decade are comparable to those from the previous five decades going back to 1960. Though from Fig. 2 the mean temperature of cold extremes is higher during the period of AA than before the period of AA.Fig. 1: Boxplots (25–75th percentiles) of the coldest 5% 2-meter temperatures in the Arctic region (70–90°N) for each decade 1960–2023.The threshold is applied for each decade separately.Full size imageFig. 2: Boxplots (25–75th percentiles) of the coldest 5% 2-meter temperatures in the CEUS region (30–50°N, 250–285°E) for each decade 1960–2023.The threshold is applied for each decade separately.Full size imageWe also note that Table 1 from Blackport and Sigmond1 (comparing a fixed threshold of cold extremes and a moving threshold of cold extremes) shows little difference in trends in cold extremes during the period of AA. In the CEUS, negative trends were found since 2000 for both methods, and in SSNC, the moving threshold resulted in a larger negative trend since 1990. In the period of AA for the CEUS and SSNC regions, only the trend in the CEUS since 1990 became statistically significant.In summary, we welcome the Blackport and Sigmond Matters Arising piece1 as it provides greater context to the trends in cold extremes across the mid-latitude continents. We emphasize that no single metric can fully capture the character and changes in extreme events. Our original paper of Cohen et al.2 and the criticism of Blackport and Sigmond1 demonstrate that identification and analysis of cold extremes are sensitive to the definition of a cold extreme. Future studies of cold extremes and trends provide greater context when multiple approaches to the analysis are used rather than just one.However, we also don’t feel that using an alternative trend computation of using a moving threshold of cold extremes negates our general conclusions that global warming has led to a detectable warming of cold extremes, but that warming is not consistent with AA in several mid-latitude locations. This is further supported by the fact that between the two methodologies for the CEUS and SSNC regions, in seven of the eight trends computed for the two definitions of the recent period, no statistically significant warming trend was found. Therefore, the alternative derivations of cold extremes in our study and that of Blackport and Sigmond1 do not necessarily produce contradictory results or conclusions. Moreover, our interpretation is not based solely on our analysis. A recent study on mid-latitude cold extremes corroborated our findings using a completely independent analysis of non-stationary generalized extreme value (GEV) distribution, which assumes non-stationary climate change as Blackport and Sigmond1 advocate. Ye et al.3 conclude: “These findings are in line with the conclusions of Cohen et al.2 that the changes in the frequency of winter cold events in some mid-latitude regions may be influenced mainly by global warming rather than by Arctic amplification”.

Data availability
              
              The ERA5 reanalysis data4 sets cover the period from 1950 to present with a resolution of approximately 30 km, which can be accessed at https://www.ecmwf.int/en/forecasts/dataset/ecmwf-reanalysis-v5.
